bioghist.p: Frank H. Verhoek, received his Ph.D. from the University of Wisconsin-Madison in 1933. He was a professor in the Chemistry Department of the Ohio State University and in 1960 became a vice-chairman of the department. The Chemical Bond Approach (CBA) was one of the major revisions to teaching of high school chemistry which emerged from the curriculum reform movement of the 1950's. The CBA Project's goal was to develop a high school chemistry curriculum that combined experimentation with theory.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists mainly of notebooks and course materials from Verhoek's undergraduate and graduate studies, as well as materials related to the Chemical Bond Approach. Verhoek's notebooks include his notes from courses in chemistry, physics and mathematics at Harvard University (1925-1929) and the University of Wisconsin (1929-1933). There are also lab record books and examination questions from a general chemistry course at the University of Wisconsin and information related to a memorial volume in 1972 for Farrington Daniels, a professor of chemistry at the University of Wisconsin. The Chemical Bond Approach materials include original drafts of two educational units Verhoek and others prepared for the 1959 meeting of the CBA at Reed College, several CBA newsletters from 1961 and 1962, other printed materials from 1964 to 1965, a report titled "The Content of Introductory College Chemistry" published by the Committee on General Chemistry of the Advisory Council on College Chemistry from 1965, and a small amount of correspondence. There are also two printed volumes on analytical chemistry written in German and a ca. 1970 typewritten history of the Department of Chemistry at the Ohio State University written by Earle R. Caby.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
